data.creator: RALDE team
data.text_p1: This virtuel practical aims to teach you the basics of cell culture. It is composed of a set of interactive elements that will introduce you to the different steps and knowledge required to master this field of expertise.
data.text_p2: You will have to interact with the different components of this VP

choices.title: Adherent cells
choices.imgText: Adherent cells are cells which must be attached to a surface to grow. They are commonly used in laboratory environments. The origin of this type of cells is usually solid tissues

choices.title: Cells in suspension
choices.imgText: A cell suspension or suspension culture is a type of cell culture in which single cells or small aggregates of cells are allowed to function and multiply in an agitated growth medium, thus forming a suspension. This type of cells is usually originate from blood.

data.text_p1: What type of cell do you want to start with?
Before starting to thaw the cells
data.text_p2: Which cells do you want to work with? Click on the link to explore the cell types.

data.text_p1: What medium is suitable for HepG2 cells ?
data.text_p2: Note: Antibiotics (penicillin and streptomycin) are optional, but commonly added to prevent bacterial infections

choices.answer: Minimum Essential Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
F-12K Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
Dulbecco’s Modified Eagles Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
RPMI-1640 Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : the correct answer can be found
data.goodAnswerText: Good job you can continue the practical

data.text_p1: What medium is suitable for A549 cells ?
data.text_p2: Note: Antibiotics (penicillin and streptomycin) are optional, but commonly added to prevent bacterial infections

choices.answer: Minimum Essential Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
F-12K Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
Dulbecco’s Modified Eagles Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%
RPMI-1640 Medium, fetal bovine serum 10%, pen/strep 1%

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : the correct answer can be found
data.goodAnswerText: Good job you can continue the practical

data.text_p1: Click on the marker to explore the different items of a cell culture laboratory
data.text_p2: (click on every single marker to continue)

card_info.title: Labcoat
card_info.text_p1: A white coat, also known as a laboratory coat or lab coat, is a knee-length overcoat or smock worn by professionals in the medical field or by those involved in laboratory work. The coat protects their street clothes and also serves as a simple uniform. The garment is made from white or light-colored cotton, linen, or cotton polyester blend, allowing it to be washed at high temperature and making it easy to see if it is clean.

card_info.title: Inverted microscope
card_info.text_p1: The degree of confluence, as well as appearance and morphology of the cells, have to be checked regularly via microscopy. When placing your cell culture consumables under the microscope, you must ensure that you are not opening the dish, flask or plate accidentally. Keep the time under the microscope as short as possible in order to avoid any unnecessary cooling of the cells. To achieve this, you should prepare the working area prior to removing the cells from the CO2 incubator

card_info.title: Water-bath
card_info.text_p1: Warm water is the ideal medium for all kinds of contaminants. In order to bring the media and other components to the ideal temperature for your cells, you will typically place the non-sterile vessels into a water bath. You will have to ensure that the caps of the vessels are not in contact with the water at any time. Bacteria and other contaminants might remain here and subsequently contaminate the inside of the vessel once it is opened. Just like the CO2 incubator, a water bath requires a regular disinfection routine. You must ensure that the water bath is emptied completely and disinfected prior to the addition of fresh water. Finally, the appropriate amounts of fungicide and bactericide should be added to the fresh water. A thermo block is a good alternative to the classic water bath - it is easier to clean and it works without water

card_info.title: Centrifuge
card_info.text_p1: Keep the lid closed. Clean rotor and chamber regularly

card_info.title: Bio safety cabinet incubator
card_info.text_p1: The principles of working in a cell culture lab become even more relevant when working in a biosafety cabinet. In general, the cabinet should be as empty as possible. Do not place or store any items in the cabinet that are not necessary for your current working procedure and do not overload it with too many dishes, plates, flasks, etc. at one time. Before starting your work you should empty the entire work area and disinfect it. Do not simply spray your disinfection solution on everything, but instead wipe the solution across the entire surface of the cabinet. Then apply the same procedure to every item that you will place into the cabinet. A working direction from 'clean' to 'dirty' should be established at this time: if you are right-handed, you might start at the left side with placing your dishes, flasks or plates and all clean, new materials such as pipette tips. In the center is your working area where you will open your consumables and change the media. The right end of the cabinet will be your designated waste area with a container for used tips, etc.

card_info.title: CO2 incubator
card_info.text_p1: The environmental conditions in a CO2 incubator are not only perfect for growing your cells, but they are also perfect for the growth of bacterial cells and fungi. Therefore, regular disinfection of the incubator is critical for the protection of your cells. The incubator should be easy to clean, which can be accomplished by a racking system which is easy to disassemble. The water in the incubator needs to be changed regularly. Make sure that you empty the water tray completely and disinfect it before you fill it with fresh sterile water. An automatic disinfection mode can help maintain sterility, especially if the chamber is not free of seams and welds.

data.text_p1: What is the correct spot to prepare the medium?

markers.title: Bench
markers.answer_text: Cell culture medium could not be prepared in the bench since it is not an sterile environment.

markers.title: flow cabinet
markers.answer_text: Cell culture medium should indeed be prepared in a sterile environment. Working under a flow cabinet helps you to maintain the sterility of your cell cultures

data.text_p1: Start the flow cabinet
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Good job: A full flow will protect cells from external contaminations and opening 1/3rd the window will allow enough air to enter the system without disturbing the laminar flow.

data.text_p1: How long should the UV lamp be left on for ?

choices.answer: 10 minutes
20 minutes
30 minutes

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Longer UV light times will not improve cabinet disinfection in routine cell culture cabinets.

data.text_p1: Put water bath at ___°C and put in the cell culture medium and buffer solutions
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: Temperatures greater than 37ºC may result in cell death

data.text_p1: Just before starting: Wipe the surface area with a tissue with ...

choices.answer: Water with detergent
70% ethanol
100% ethanol

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: 100% coagulates membrane proteins so fast that the contaminants get inactive but do not die. 70% ethanol penetrates cell membranes slower so that it can really reach the center of the contaminants and kill them.

data.text_p1: To spray the ethanol it is best to use

choices.answer: Spray bottle
Glass bottle with big opening
Squeeze bottle

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Squeeze bottle deliver the right amount of alcohol

data.text_p1: Select the correct position to work in the flow cabinet

choices.answer: In the front
In the middle
In the back

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Walls and objects disturb the laminar flow, therefore the best place to work is the middle of the cabinet. Moreover, the front part of the cabinet is the part with the highest contamination risk since it is the closest to the end of the laminar flow and is easily disturbed by slight movements.

data.text_p1: Start the flow cabinet
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Having the flow cabinet full of things will disturb he flow of the air and thus disrupt the sterile environment

answers.text: The things we need plus a container/s to put the 'garbage', tips

data.text_p1: The incubator for growing the cells should be kept at:

choices.answer: 37° C and 5% CO2
37° C and 10% CO2
45° C and 5% CO2
45° C and 10% CO2

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: human and mammalian cell lines should be kept at 37ºC for optimal growth, 5% CO2 is needed to buffer the system to ensure that the normal physiological pH is maintained for optimum cell growth

data.text_p1: What do you need to wear in order to take the cells? More than one answer may be correct
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Liquid Nitrogen is dangerous and may burn your skin if little drops reach you

data.text_p1: Select the correct place to thaw the cells
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Fast thawing will result in greater cell viability

data.text_p1: How to process thawn cells?

choices.answer: Spin at 150-300 g for 5 min to remove freezing medium and dilute 10 x in cell culture medium
Quick spin at 13000xg for 1min to remove freezing medium
Dilute 10x in cell culture medium and centrifuge  to remove freezing medium(5 min, 150-300 g, RT)

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Dilute first the cryoprotectant so that is no longer toxic and then spin down in order to get rid of it.

data.text_p1: Select the correct culture material
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells are maintained in culture flasks. Cryotubes normally contain low number of cells so a T25 would keep cells closer to each other avoiding low density-related stress.

data.text_p1: Put the correct volume of medium to the T25

choices.answer: Final volume of 1 mL
Final volume of 3 mL
Final volume of 5 mL

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Lower volumes than 5 mL may result in insufficient nutrients for the cells

data.text_p1: How will you label the flask? What are the crucial information that needs to be written?
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: The type of medium is cell-line specific so it is sufficient to just write the cell type, cell concentration is not necessary for adherent cell maintenance, volume of medium is the same for every flask size (i.e., 5 mL for T25)

data.text_p1: Put the cells in the correct incubator

choices.answer: 37° C, 5% CO2 and humidity
37° C and 5% CO2
37° C, 5% CO2 and humidity

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: 5% CO2 is needed to balance the pH of the medium and humidity is needed to prevent excessive evaporation of the medium

data.text_p1: Select the correct position of the cell culture flasks if the cap has no filter in it

choices.answer: Horizontal - cap closed
Horizontal - open cap for a quarter turn
Horizontal - fully opened cap
Vertical - cap closed
Vertical - open cap for a quarter turn
Vertical - fully opened cap

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Caps without filter need to be a little open so that there is gas exchange between the cells and the incubator. The flask must be placed horizontal so that cell will attached to the treated surface of the flask.

data.text_p1: When will you check how your cells are growing after thawing?

choices.answer: After two hours
In the evening of the same day
The next day
After two days

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Adherent cells need time to attach to the flask. The act of removing the flask from the incubator before they are fully attach may result in breaking the incipient bonds.

data.text_p1: Before starting subculturing the cells
data.text_p2: Which cells do you want to work with? Click on the link to explore the cell types.

data.text_p1: Check cell confluency. At was confluency should you subculture your cells?
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells should be in an optimal state in order to undergo trypsinization (80% confluency). At higher densities, cells are stressed and their behaviour may change, they can even mutate.

data.text_p1: Which of these pictures represents 80% confluency? (answers with pictures)
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: 100% confluence means that there is no more room for cells to grow, at this state they can only start dying.

data.text_p1: How does the medium look like?

choices.answer: Still good
Partially saturated
Saturated

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Explanation: Na₂HCO₃ and CO₂ need to be balanced in the medium so that pH stays neutral (pH 7=red). When the number of cells increases, the amount of CO₂ increases, too, due to their respiration. That shifts the balance to H+ production, decreasing the pH of the medium (yellow).  H₂O + CO₂ + NaHCO₃ ⟷ H⁺ + Na⁺ + 2HCO₃₋

data.text_p1: What does it mean if you have a sudden turn of color to intense yellow in your medium?

choices.answer: Cells should be fine. It is a normal adjustment of pH inside the incubator
Cells should be fine. Yellow color only means that the pH has decreased due to normal cell respiration
Cells may not be fine. There may be a contamination inside the flask

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Sudden acidity of the medium indicate the presence of more living organisms than just the cell line. The release of CO₂ increases in great proportion due to the respiration of the cells and the contaminants and it leads to an intense yellow color of the medium.

data.text_p1: Regarding contamination, choose the right answer:

choices.answer: Cells can get multiple types of contaminations at the same time.
Cells can get multiple types of contaminations but only one at a time
Cells can only get contaminations of bacteria and yeast but only one at a time
Cells can only get contaminations of fungi and viruses but only one at a time

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Most microscopic organisms love complete medium and they can all contaminate at the same time

data.text_p1: Do you have a contamination? Match the contamination type with the right picture, if applicable

possible_answers.text: No contamination but cells are dying

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, at least one picture is bad labelled
data.goodAnswerText: All pictures where matched with the correct label

data.text_p1: How will you proceed if you have a bacteria/yeast/fungi contamination? More than one answer may be correct
data.badAnswerText: Bad answer, please re-read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Aerosols of all the contaminants from inside and outside the flask may contaminate the incubator/cabinet and infect other people’s flasks. Everybody should be aware of a contamination on anyone’s cells in order to keep a close eye on their cells. Medium would normally also be contaminated if cells are but it won’t show signs of contamination until much later since it is kept at 4ºC, a temperature that decreases growth of any living organism

answers.text: I’d discard the cells and disinfect the incubator if bacteria or yeast are in he flask, but I’ll only change the medium in case of fungi contamination since they are big and easy to remove
I’d discard my cells and everybody else’s and disinfect the incubator
I’d discard my cells and disinfect the incubator and cabinets. The rest of cells will go to a quarantine incubator
I’d discard the medium if I see turbidity or any kind of contamination signs inside it

data.text_p1: If cells are at 80% confluency a passage should be performed. How would you do it? Order all the steps you’d take. (All steps shown may not be necessary)
data.badAnswerText: Bad order : try again
data.goodAnswerText: Good job you can continue the practical

choices.answer: Remove the medium
Remove the medium
Add fresh medium (37ºC) into a flask (T25 ot T75) (We can explain why one or other)
Add PBS (37ºC) to the flask and wash the cell monolayer
Check if the cells are detached under the microscope
Collect the cells in a tube
If detached: add fresh medium (37ºC) on top of the trypsin
Place the cells in the incubator for 5-15 min
Place the flask with the cells in the incubator
Remove the PBS
Transfer an aliquot of the cell suspension (l) to the falsk (m)
Take an aliquot to count

data.text_p1: How would you perform a passage if your cells are in 5 mL and you want to subculture them at 1:5 in a T75?

choices.answer: Add 5 mL medium to the cells, transfer 3 mL to a new T75 and add 10 mL to the new flask
Take the 5 mL of the flask and transfer them to a new T75. Then add 10 mL complete medium
Add 10 mL complete medium to the flask and transfer 3 mL to anew T75
Add 14 mL complete medium to a new T75 and transfer 1 mL from the original flask

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Sudden acidity of the medium indicate the presence of more living organisms than just the cell line. The release of CO₂ increases in great proportion due to the respiration of the cells and the contaminants and it leads to an intense yellow color of the medium.

data.text_p1: Prepare reagents for cryopreservation. Choose the most appropriate answer

choices.answer: Complete growth medium supplemented with 5-10% (v/v) DMSO
Complete growth medium containing 10% FBS
Growth medium with 40% FBS and 10% DMSO
FBS with 20% of DMSO

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells can be frozen in FBS or medium but always with a cryoprotectant such as DMSO to remove water from the inside of the cells and prevent membrane rupture after freezing. Percentages greater than 10% DMSO may result in cell death

data.text_p1: Count the cells. How do you do it? Choose the most appropriate answer.

choices.answer: I can only count them under a microscope, automatic counting leads to too many errors
I can only count them with an automatic counter, manual counting leads to too many errors
Cells can be counted indistinctly under the microscope or with an automatic counter. The only difference is the price of the automatic chambers
Both methods are valid, as long as you maintain the method used through experiments of the same type

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Cells can be frozen in FBS or medium but always with a cryoprotectant such as DMSO to remove water from the inside of the cells and prevent membrane rupture after freezing. Percentages greater than 10% DMSO may result in cell death

data.text_p1: What do you see when you use Trypan blue for cell counting?

choices.answer: Blue cells are the living ones
Blue cells are the dead ones
Blue cells have the membrane damaged.

data.badAnswerText: Bad answer : please re read your notes
data.goodAnswerText: Trypan blue can only enter the cells if the membrane is damaged. Therefore, although damaged membranes normally result in cell death, it is not correct to say that blue cells are dead since there may be a population that is just damaged but that may recover
